title: 105_hr3315
content: The "Fair Elections and Political Accountability Act" removes limitations on federal election campaign contributions starting after 1998 and promotes expedited availability of FEC reports while lowering the threshold for disclosure of contributors' identification. The "Fair Elections and Political Accountability Act" amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require electronic filing of reports and notification of contributions over $100 within 60 days of an election. The "Fair Elections and Political Accountability Act" mandates timely reporting of contributions, including candidate details, contributor identification, and amount received. Political committees must notify authorities if returning a contribution. Additionally, electronic disclosure of campaign finance reports is required by the Commission. The "Fair Elections and Political Accountability Act" requires prompt disclosure of contributions, with reports available online and at the Commission's offices within 24 hours. The Act also lowers the threshold for identifying contributors. The "Fair Elections and Political Accountability Act" mandates quicker disclosure of contributions to political committees, with details like contributor's name, address, and date of receipt required to be forwarded to the treasurer within 10 days of receiving the contribution. The Act also reduces the threshold for reporting contributions. The amendment to the "Fair Elections and Political Accountability Act" eliminates the requirement for political committees to keep information on contributions exceeding $200. Effective January 1, 1999, this amendment applies to reports starting from that date. SEC. 4 prohibits contributions by foreign nationals and individuals not qualified to vote in federal elections. Sec. 319 prohibits foreign nationals from making contributions to political campaigns and individuals not qualified to vote in federal elections. Individuals not qualified to register to vote in federal elections are prohibited from making contributions or soliciting contributions for any political office or primary election. The amendments made by this section apply to elections occurring after January 1999. SEC. 5. FUNDING OF POLITICAL ACTIVITIES BY CORPORATIONS AND LABOR ORGANIZATIONS. Prohibiting donation of funds to political parties by national banks, corporations, and labor organizations under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Effective from elections after January 1999. Prohibiting national banks and corporations from involuntarily collecting funds from employees for Federal campaign activities without prior written authorization. Prohibiting labor organizations from collecting dues for Federal campaign activities without prior written authorization from members. Authorization remains in effect until revoked and individuals must be provided with the option to revoke at any time. Federal campaign activity defined as influencing elections for Federal office. The amendment prohibits labor organizations from collecting dues for Federal campaign activities without prior written authorization from members. The amendment applies to amounts collected or assessed on or after the date of the enactment of this Act. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to prohibit contributions during the six months following a general election. Labor organizations are also prohibited from collecting dues for Federal campaign activities without prior written authorization from members. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to prohibit contributions to a candidate's political committee for a Federal office during the 180-day period after a general election, unless it is a runoff or special election. Contributions for expenses of a previous election are exempt. The amendments apply to elections after January 1999. Additionally, there is an increase in authorization of appropriations for the Federal Election Commission. Section 314 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to authorize $60,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2001, with a minimum of $28,350,000 allocated for enforcement activities. This enhances the enforcement of campaign finance laws. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase mandatory imprisonment for criminal conduct, with a minimum of 1 year and a maximum of 10 years. The Attorney General is granted concurrent authority to bring criminal actions for violations of the Act or related tax codes. The amendments made by this section apply to actions brought for elections after January 1999.
